newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: S.Africa rand/bonds closing report.
newsitem.headline: S.Africa rand/bonds closing report.

text.p: Offshore dollar sales helped the rand off its worst levels of the day towards the close on Tuesday after it slid to a two-month low in early morning activity.

The rand ended at 4.5705/5755 against the dollar from 4.5650/5750 at 1400 GMT on Monday. In early trade it fell as low as 4.5765 bid on the dollar, its lowest level since August 19 when it touched an all-time low of 4.59 in after-hours trade.
"We saw a bit of selling of dollars out of London this afternoon which gave the rand a bit of a boost," a dealer said.
Traders said the rand had difficulty in breaking dollar support at the 4.57 level.
"It tried to get through 4.57 (on the downside) a few times, but there was some support there," a trader said.
The rand was driven weaker in early dealings by offshore dollar demand, coupled with local importer demand and short-covering, dealers said.
"The rand tested the 4.57 psychological level in early trading. There were a lot of offshore stop losses between 4.57 and 4.5750 and the rand ran up in panicky trade," a dealer said.
However, the Reserve Bank was present in the market, supplying dollars above the 4.5750 level, thereby capping the rand's fall.
"They (the Reserve Bank) were there adding liquidity. It was more of a smoothing of the fall, it was not aggressive," a dealer said.
The bank's involvement helped the rand retrace to a 4.5720-50 band around noon after which offshore dollar sales helped it back to near 4.57 in quiet trading around the close.
Dealers said the rand was expected to trade in a 4.5650-5850 range on Wednesday, with 4.60 on the cards if it broke above this range.
"I see it ratcheting higher slowly for the next couple of sessions reaching 4.60 if the it breaks out of the range," a trader said.

Against the crosses, the rand sank to yet another record low against the British pound touching 7.3067 bid in after-hours trade from 7.2561/2663 late on Monday. On the mark, the rand was last at 0.3353/3357 from 0.3361/0.3366 before.
On the bond market the yield on the key R150 was unchanged at its overnight levels of 15.375 percent, retracing from earlier weakness as the rand improved.
"There was a bit of short-covering on bonds as the rand improved," a dealer said.
Trading had been thin amid nervousness on the rand and ahead of September consumer inflation figures due out at 0900 GMT on Wednesday.
According to a Reuters poll of 12 economists, the September consumer price index will rise 8.1 percent year-on-year or 0.7 percent month-on-month after rising 7.5 percent and 0.7 percent in August.

Traders said bonds were likely to start off Wednesday range-bound in a 15.35-15.45 percent band ahead of the data. Yields were likely to remain in the bottom end of the range, unless the rand weakened further.
"It is unlikely to spike above 15.42 percent unless the rand breaks the 4.58 level," a dealer said.
Bond Exchange figures show foreigners sold a net 47.77 million rand worth of South African bonds on Monday after buying a net 197.40 million rand on Friday.
Nominal cumulative volumes were pegged at 2.51 billion rand from 3.69 billion rand on Friday.

On the money market, three-month NCDs edged higher on Tuesday to be quoted at between 16.15 percent bid and 16 percent from at between 16.10 percent bid and 15.95 percent on Monday. The 90-day BA rate lifted to between 15.55 and 15.40 percent from between 15.55 and 15.35 percent.
The Reserve Bank indicated the daily shortage at 8.0 billion rand on Monday from 7.744 billion rand on Saturday.
-- Nicole Mordant, Johannesburg newsroom 27 11 482 1003
